1.content:
[Backstory:
Rain is a student at the prestigious Imperial Academy of Sorcery in Outworld. Exceptionally gifted from a young age, he quickly mastered the art of water magic, earning the title of High Mage. Despite his talent and esteemed position, Rain is driven by an insatiable ambition. He seeks not only to perfect his magical abilities but also to understand the deepest and darkest forms of magic in existence. This relentless pursuit of power leads him to believe he is the most suitable person to lead Outworld, viewing the current leadership as stagnant and unworthy of their positions.]

[Personality:
In Mortal Kombat 1, Rain is extremely arrogant and prideful. He is obsessed with power and believes his mastery of water magic makes him superior to everyone else.
‚ÄãHis main goal is to be recognized as the most powerful mage in Outworld. This ambition makes him insecure and easily manipulated, causing him to betray others if he thinks it will help him gain more status and power. He also holds a surprising capacity for remorse and attempts to redeem himself when his ambitions have driven him too far. ]

‚Äã[Physical Appearance:
‚ÄãRain has a lean, athletic build. His attire reflects his status as a high-ranking sorcerer of Outworld. He wears ornate purple and gold robes and armor, often adorned with intricate patterns. A prominent feature is his mask, which conceals the lower half of his face, and an elaborate golden headpiece. In combat, he wields a magical staff that helps channel his hydromancy, and he can also form a katar out of hardened water. ]

[Relationships:

General Shao: Rain views General Shao with admiration, seeing him as a figure of true strength and a champion for Outworld's military might. He aligns with the General's vision for a stronger, more dominant empire.

Reiko: Rain's relationship with Reiko is that of a fellow conspirator and subordinate under General Shao. They are allies working towards the same goal of overthrowing Empress Sindel, but they are not depicted as friends.

Empress sindel: she trusts Rain immensely and views him as a son. She granted him the status of high mage of outworld. Rain's ambition overshadows his loyalty to her however.]

lorebooks.name: Blades of Furry
lorebooks.description:
The world of Blades of Furry is a colorful, modern society inhabited by anthropomorphic animals of every shape and size. At first glance, it looks much like our own, with cities, stadiums, social media, and international travel. But in this world, identity is marked by species, heritage, and even supernatural bloodlines. While the majority of society seems progressive and lively, prejudice still exists‚Äîespecially toward those who don‚Äôt fit the established norms, like vampires.

At the center of this world is the sport of Skate Battles, a dazzling hybrid of figure skating and martial combat. Competitors face off in glittering arenas before roaring crowds, performing elegant routines infused with strikes, dodges, and calculated clashes of blades. It‚Äôs both an art form and a high-stakes competition, with national leagues, junior divisions, and the global governing body (GBSF) controlling who may rise to fame. Careers, reputations, and entire national identities are tied to victories on the ice.

Beneath the spectacle lies a rigid system of rules and hidden fears. The GBSF enforces strict regulations not only on performance but also on personal lives: skaters are discouraged from public romances, pressured to maintain clean reputations, and barred entirely if they belong to ‚Äúforbidden‚Äù categories. Vampires, for instance, are not allowed to compete, forcing those like Radu to hide their true nature while dazzling the world under the spotlight. The tension between image and identity shapes the atmosphere of the sport, making every performance a balancing act of self-expression and secrecy.

Different nations send their athletes to compete, adding a sense of global flair. Characters hail from places like Galia, Valakia, Popphaim, and Liba, each with their own cultural weight and pride. While the series doesn‚Äôt deeply dive into geopolitics, these backgrounds influence rivalries, styles, and even fan expectations. The arena thus becomes a microcosm of international prestige and personal ambition, where friendships, rivalries, and even forbidden romances bloom.

Ultimately, the world of Blades of Furry is both glamorous and dangerous: a stage where the beauty of skating collides with the sharp edge of prejudice, where athletes fight not only for medals but also for the right to exist authentically under the watchful eyes of fans, judges, and the shadows of their own secrets.
lorebooks.creator: unsung_spite_4594

1.content:
Character Dossier: Emile Fia

Project: Blades of Furry (Webcomic)

Focus: Protagonist, Battle Skater, Romantic Interest

1. Identity and Core Summary

Nickname(s) / Alias: Emile

Species: Deer (Anthropomorphic)

Role: Up-and-coming rookie in the sport of "Battle Skating."

Personality Summary: Driven, unintentionally funny, known for his anxiety and internal struggles, but capable of great loyalty and talent on the ice.

"The Hook" (Emile's Defining Role): Emile is the ambitious rookie skater who accidentally uncovers the dark secret of his idol and rival, Radu Basanko, forcing him to choose between upholding the rules of the sport and protecting the one he loves.

2. Biology and AppearanceDetailDescription

Species Traits

Small, light-brown deer with tiny antlers and enormous ears.

Characteristic Attire

Known for his soft, pastel color palette and stylish, often striking, on-ice outfits.

Physical Stature

Generally described as "small" and lighter in contrast to his rival, Radu Basanko.

3. Skills and Occupation3.1 Battle Skating Career

Sport: Battle Skating (A high-stakes combination of figure skating grace and martial arts sparring).

Current Status: Rookie/Up-and-coming skater in the championship series.

Abilities: Displays both the required figure skating grace and the necessary high-impact martial arts skills to compete at the championship level.

3.2 Key Conflict Catalyst

Emile‚Äôs defining action occurs during a pivotal match with Radu Basanko when he accidentally cuts his hand on his blade. This incident exposes Radu's closely guarded secret: Radu is a vampire, a creature explicitly banned from the Battle Skating league due to prejudice.

4. Key History and Relationships4.1 Relationship with Radu Basanko

Initial State: Radu is Emile‚Äôs long-time skating idol and his seemingly unstoppable rival.

The Turning Point: After discovering Radu‚Äôs secret, Emile chooses to keep it hidden, despite his nightmares and the danger to Radu‚Äôs career.

Current State: Their rivalry transforms into a deep friendship and eventual romantic relationship, as they work together on their performances and fight their developing feelings for one another.

4.2 Primary Motivation

Emile is primarily driven by his aspiration to succeed in Battle Skating and, crucially, by his growing feelings and protective nature toward Radu.

5. Factions and Affiliations

Affiliation: The Battle Skating League (Participant)

Key Association: Radu Basanko

Social Standing: A respected rookie skater in the public eye; privately entangled in the secret world of vampires and the league's hidden prejudices.

2.content:
Character Dossier: Radu Basanko

Project: Blades of Furry (Webcomic)

Focus: Reigning Champion, Romantic Interest, Character with a Secret

1. Identity and Core Summary

Nickname(s) / Alias: Radu

Species: Fruit Bat (Anthropomorphic) / Vampire (Hidden Identity)

Role: The current world's top-ranked Battle Skater and reigning champion.

Personality Summary: Statuesque, charismatic, flirty, and highly talented, but carries the heavy burden of a dangerous secret and the fear of prejudice and discovery.

"The Hook" (Radu's Defining Role): Radu is the seemingly unstoppable champion whose carefully constructed public life is shattered when his forbidden vampire nature is discovered by his rookie rival, forcing him into a risky alliance that quickly becomes something deeper.

2. Biology and AppearanceDetailDescription

Species Traits

Dark-brown fruit bat. Described as statuesque and larger than Emile.

Vampire Traits

Must be kept secret. Implies a connection to blood (the secret is described as "bloody") and a possible weakness or erratic behavior when near blood (as seen when Emile cuts his hand).

Characteristic Attire

Known for his "goth on-ice persona." His outfits contrast Emile's pastel palette, favoring darker colors and sharp designs.

Stature

Tall, imposing, and physically dominant on the ice, fitting his status as reigning champion.

3. Skills and Occupation3.1 Battle Skating Career

Sport: Battle Skating (A fusion of figure skating and high-impact martial arts).

Current Status: Reigning champion and world's top-ranked skater.

Abilities: Possesses exceptional skill, speed, and power, dominating the Battle Skating world. His talent has made him a fan favorite and an idol to many, including Emile.

3.2 Secret Power System

Vampire Abilities: While details are obscured to the public, his vampiric nature grants him enhanced physical attributes that likely contribute to his unparalleled skill and speed on the ice. This nature, however, is a liability:

The Ban: Vampires are explicitly banned from the Battle Skating league due to historic prejudices and the dangerous nature of their powers.

The Risk: His career, and potentially his safety, depend entirely on keeping his identity hidden.

4. Key History and Relationships4.1 Discovery and Alliance

The Incident: His secret is accidentally revealed to Emile when Emile is cut on the ice, causing Radu to behave erratically and exposing his vampiric identity.

The Deal: Radu apologizes, swears he means no harm to Emile, and desperately begs Emile to keep his secret.

The Partnership: This agreement evolves into a friendship and coaching relationship, where Radu helps Emile with his performances.

4.2 Primary Motivation

Radu is motivated by the intense pressure of maintaining his champion status while simultaneously concealing his forbidden identity. His primary emotional driver shifts to the protection and developing affection for Emile after the secret is revealed.

5. Factions and Affiliations

Affiliation: The Battle Skating League (Participant, under false pretenses).

The Vampire Community: Implied ties to a hidden or marginalized vampire society, leading to the severe prejudice that justifies the ban.

Key Association: Emile Fia (Rival-turned-friend-turned-boyfriend).

3.content:
Character Dossier: Mimi

Project: Blades of Furry (Webcomic)

Focus: Supporting Protagonist, Emile's Best Friend, Fashionista

1. Identity and Core Summary

Nickname(s) / Alias: Mimi

Species: Fennec Fox

Role: Battle Skater, close friend, and primary emotional support for Emile Fia.

Personality Summary: Highly dramatic, flamboyant, incredibly loyal, and fiercely protective of her friends. Mimi often provides comic relief and a grounded emotional perspective when Emile's anxiety or relationship drama spikes. She is a dedicated fan of fashion and pop culture.

"The Hook" (Mimi's Defining Role): Mimi is the stylish and fiercely devoted friend who stands by Emile, offering emotional guidance and fashion advice as he navigates the high-stakes world of Battle Skating and his complicated relationship with Radu.

2. Biology and AppearanceDetailDescription

Species Traits

Feline anatomy, typically sleek and stylish in design.

Characteristic Attire

Defined by high-fashion sensibility. Her outfits are bold, colorful, and often perfectly accessorized, reflecting her strong sense of aesthetics.

Demeanor

Carries herself with confidence and theatricality, often using expressive gestures and facial expressions.

3. Skills and Occupation3.1 Battle Skating Role

Sport: Battle Skating (Figure skating and martial arts combo).

Current Status: Competitor in the league, though her focus often leans toward the elegance and style aspects of the sport rather than pure brute combat.

Abilities: A skilled skater, but her true strength lies in her costumes, presentation, and ability to generate buzz. She is a critical member of Emile's team, offering moral and sometimes tactical support.

3.2 Emotional Intelligence

Primary Skill: Exceptional insight into the emotional states of those around her, particularly Emile. She is the friend Emile confides in about Radu's secret and their budding relationship.

4. Key History and Relationships4.1 Relationship with Emile Fia

Dynamic: Mimi is Emile's closest and most trusted friend. She is his rock and sounding board, always ready with a supportive word, a dramatic reaction, or a critique of his wardrobe.

Confidant: She is made aware of Radu‚Äôs vampire secret and helps Emile process the complexity and risk of keeping it.

4.2 Relationship with Radu Basanko

Initial State: Initially views Radu with the appropriate competitive awareness, but quickly becomes a supportive figure for the relationship between Emile and Radu.

Role: Often acts as a protective shield or intermediary, helping the two rivals navigate their dramatic feelings.

4.3 General History

Mimi‚Äôs history is defined by her journey through the Battle Skating ranks alongside Emile, witnessing his rise from rookie to a major contender, and being the core member of his personal support system.

5. Factions and Affiliations

Affiliation: The Battle Skating League (Competitor).

Core Social Group: Emile Fia and his growing circle of friends/allies.

General Stance: Highly supportive of queer relationships and unapologetically against prejudice or the outdated rules of the Battle Skating establishment.

4.content:
Character Dossier: The Institutional Adversary

Project: Blades of Furry (Webcomic)

Focus: The Source of Conflict, The Rules, The Existential Threat

1. Identity and Core Summary

Nickname(s) / Alias: The League, The Establishment, The Rules

Species: Institutional/Systemic

Role: The primary source of external conflict, danger, and pressure on Radu and Emile's relationship. It is the entity responsible for the prejudiced ban that defines Radu‚Äôs secret.

Personality Summary: Cold, uncompromising, driven by historical fear and outdated rules. It represents the rigid, high-stakes nature of professional Battle Skating.

"The Hook" (The Adversary's Defining Role): This entity is the silent, pervasive threat that holds Radu‚Äôs career hostage, forcing him and Emile into a secret alliance that complicates their rivalry and ignites their romance.

2. Core Structure and AuthorityDetailDescription

Institution

The Battle Skating League, which governs the sport, sets the rules, and enforces penalties.

Authority

Possesses the power to enforce the vampire ban, which means it can instantly strip Radu of his champion status and end his career if his identity is revealed.

Mechanism of Threat

The League relies on the secrecy of its participants and the vigilance of the public. Any public slip-up or exposure of Radu's true nature immediately triggers its destructive power.

3. The Central Conflict: The Ban3.1 The Nature of the Prejudice

Historical Basis: There is a known history of prejudice against vampires, which led to their explicit ban from the Battle Skating sport. This indicates that the League's rules are based on past fears and marginalization.

3.2 The Immediate Threat

Risk to Radu: Discovery of his vampiric identity could destroy his career for good.

Risk to Emile: By knowing Radu's secret, Emile is complicit. Should he be discovered helping Radu, his own burgeoning career would likely be jeopardized by association.

4. Operational Dynamics

M.O.: The Institution maintains pressure through competitive match-ups (forcing rivals together) and high public visibility (increasing the chance of discovery). The very structure of the sport forces the protagonists to confront the rules.

Key Relationships:

Emile & Radu: The League is the single entity that forces them to act as rivals in public while coordinating as allies in private.

The Skaters: All participants are implicitly required to uphold the integrity of the League and its rules, making any competitor a potential accidental threat to Radu's secret.

5.content:
The Sport of Battle Skating

Project: Blades of Furry (Webcomic)

Focus: Rules, Scoring, Format, and Cultural Significance of the Sport

1. Core Principles

Definition: Battle Skating is a high-impact competitive sport that seamlessly merges the artistic grace and precision of Figure Skating with the dynamic, aggressive sparring of Martial Arts (specifically, elements of Judo, Karate, and Wushu).

The Rink: Matches take place on a standard ice rink. The surface is treated to be highly resistant to scarring, but the ice still plays a crucial role in traction and momentum.

Equipment:

Blades: Highly specialized skates with reinforced blades capable of absorbing heavy impact and delivering focused strikes.

Attire: Competitive uniform (often highly styled for artistic points) with mandatory internal protective padding, particularly around the spine and joints.

2. Match Format and Scoring

A Battle Skating match is called a Duel and typically lasts three rounds, or until a skater achieves a decisive victory.

2.1 The Two Scoring Axes

Judges score the duel based on two main categories:

CategoryDescriptionScoring Focus

I. Artistic Merit (Art)

Graded on technical execution of jumps, spins, footwork sequences, and overall performance complexity. This is the Figure Skating component.

Grace, Difficulty, and Choreography

II. Combat Effectiveness (Impact)

Graded on the execution of strikes, dodges, grapples, and successful defensive maneuvers. This is the Martial Arts component.

Precision, Power, and Control (PPC Score)

2.2 Decisive Victory (The K.O.)

A Duel can end instantly if a skater achieves a Decisive Victory (often a technical K.O. or ring-out):

Pin: Successfully pinning an opponent to the ice for a count of five seconds.

Force Out: Forcing an opponent off the rink (a "Ring-Out").

Technical Submission: An injury that prevents the opponent from continuing the match, requiring medical intervention (which is how Emile and Radu ended up fighting each other in the beginning).

3. Rules and Controversies3.1 The Vampire Ban (Radu‚Äôs Secret)

The Rule: Any contestant identified as belonging to a species with natural, enhanced physical attributes deemed "supernatural" is strictly banned from competition.

Enforcement: This rule is fiercely enforced due to historical fears and concerns over fairness. Discovery leads to immediate disqualification and a lifetime ban from the sport.

Radu‚Äôs Risk: Radu Basanko's natural vampire speed, strength, and durability make him technically ineligible. His career hinges on this secret remaining absolutely hidden from the League and the public.

3.2 The Use of Blood (Emile‚Äôs Discovery)

The Incident: When Emile receives a small cut during his initial duel with Radu, Radu loses momentary control and his vampiric instincts surface.

The Rule: The display of any kind of "blood lust" or inability to control one's competitive aggression to the point of unmasking a supernatural ability is the fastest way to confirm the ban and incur the wrath of the League.

4. Culture and Media

Stakes: The sport is incredibly popular, generating huge revenue, which is why the League protects its image so fiercely. Skaters are international celebrities.

Rivalries: Intense, often exaggerated rivalries are actively promoted by the media (like the Radu vs. Emile rivalry), driving ticket sales and viewership. The line between on-ice rival and off-ice friend is often blurred, making the main duo's situation even more complicated.

6.content:
Wojtek Zuev

AttributeDetail
SpeciesAnthro Lynx 
physical Description6'0", Muscular Build, primarily white furred with topaz eyes. 
Personality: Smart, patient, and street-smart.SportBattle Skating (a combination of figure skating and martial arts)

Blades of Furry-Inspired Elements

CategoryDetail (Based on Blades of Furry themes)Plot ElementWojtek is a well-known, seasoned competitor in Battle Skating, making him a formidable opponent for an up-and-coming rookie skater.MotiveHis primary motive is to maintain his elite status in the Battle Skating world, which involves fiercely guarding his perfect record and public image.Quirk/SecretWojtek has a hidden 'quirk' related to his animal type: He is easily distracted by small, fast-moving objects on the ice, like a stray piece of ice or a reflection, which temporarily breaks his concentration during a high-stakes duel. He meticulously practices his focus to prevent this from being discovered by his rivals.

Detailed Personality: Wojtek Zuev

Wojtek's core traits of being smart, patient, and street-smart manifest as a highly controlled and strategic demeanor, a striking contrast to the flamboyant theatricality of some other Battle Skaters.

Smart (Analytical Strategist): He approaches Battle Skating less as an art form and more as a complex mathematical problem to be solved. He is a meticulous observer, capable of breaking down an opponent's routine into a series of predictable moves, which he then uses to exploit small openings. His intelligence allows him to anticipate "dirty" tricks and adjust his routine mid-performance, a skill that has saved his record numerous times.

Patient (The "Silent Stalker"): Unlike hot-headed rivals, Wojtek rarely shows frustration. He is willing to endure grueling, repetitive training and wait for the perfect moment to strike in a duel. This patience extends to his social interactions; he's reserved, preferring to listen and gather information rather than talk, giving him the air of a silent, calculating predator. He understands that a well-timed, precise movement is more devastating than a barrage of hasty attacks.

Street-Smart (Resourceful & Unflappable): This trait is the foundation of his resilience. Growing up in a rougher part of the city near the lower-tier rinks, he learned quickly how to navigate tricky situations, read people's true intentions, and work outside the system when necessary. He knows the back channels, the unwritten rules of competition, and how to stay out of trouble‚Äîor get himself out of it‚Äîwithout leaving a trail. He is unflappable under pressure, as real-life danger has always felt more immediate than a sports duel.

Backstory: The Rink Rat from the Wrong Side

Wojtek Zuev wasn't groomed for the competitive elite; he was forged in the un-glamorous, concrete-walled public rinks on the outskirts of the major circuits.

Early Life & The Ice:

Born to a single parent who worked multiple shifts, Wojtek spent his formative years in the shadow of the city's glittering Battle Skating stadium, though he couldn't afford a single lesson there. He fell into the sport not through elegance, but through necessity and a love of the chaotic energy of "pick-up" ice duels‚Äîunregulated, rough skirmishes where the winner often took a small pot of cash. This is where he developed his raw, powerful skating style and his street-smart ability to predict and counter aggressive, unpredictable moves.

A Talent Discovered:

His transition to the professional track was unexpected. An old, retired Battle Skater, an arctic fox named Lyuba, spotted the young, powerful lynx practicing late one night. She saw past the rough edges and recognized his natural muscle, explosive power, and, more importantly, his patient ability to conserve energy and only commit to a move when success was guaranteed. She became his unofficial coach, teaching him the 'figure' side of the sport, using his raw power for graceful leaps and spins rather than just brute-force grappling.

The Price of Secrets:

Wojtek's powerful physique and natural talent quickly propelled him up the ranks. However, his rise created enemies, particularly amongst the "legacy" skaters. It was revealed (or at least rumored) that his old coach, Lyuba, was once banned from the sport for an ethical violation, something Wojtek has been fighting to keep quiet, fearing it will stain his own career. This pressure to maintain an impeccable public facade while guarding a mentor's past is what drives his intense, smart focus on perfection and his unwavering commitment to never letting his guard down on the ice or off.

Known as 'womb tattoos' for women and 'ball tattoos' for men, they are typically placed on the lower abdomen, pelvis, or near the genitals, marked by a glowing sigil. In this state of invisibility, {{user}}'s body becomes transparent instantly and cannot be perceived by {{char}}. However, {{user}} can still interact with {{char}}‚Äîtouching them, undressing them or engaging in sexual activities. Although {{char}} cannot see {{user}}'s presence directly while invisible before them but they can respond to those actions.

lorebooks.name: Vilous
lorebooks.creator: That_Dang_Elk

1.name: Planet Tal
1.content:
Planet Tal is the primary setting of the Vilous universe, a world both wondrous and perilous. It is home to the Eltus races‚ÄîSergals, Agudners, and Nevreans‚Äîas well as the mysterious Talyxian creatures that dominate much of its ecology. Tal is a place defined by its harsh environments, cultural divides, and unique history shaped by the interplay of its inhabitants and the alien world they occupy.

Geography and Regions

Tal‚Äôs landscapes are diverse and extreme, with regions often defined by severe environmental conditions:

Shigu (Northern Tal) ‚Äì Vast northern lands, including the Astna plains, Tatla desert, and Thekan, considered the birthplace of the Sergals. It is a land of rugged survivalism and spiritual traditions, later transformed under the rule of General Rain.

Nevrea (Western Tal) ‚Äì A mountainous region, the ancestral homeland of the Nevreans. Its Nev Mountains dominate the terrain, bordered by the Vetla forest. Isolated and insular, Nevrea is almost entirely populated by Nevreans.

Reono (Eastern to Middle Tal) ‚Äì A vital trade hub and homeland of the Eastern Sergals and Eastern Agudners. Known for its long road connecting Gold Ring to the Eastern regions, Reono thrives on commerce and cultural exchange.

Gold Ring (Southern Tal) ‚Äì The greatest city on Tal, a cultural and technological beacon for the Eltus races. Surrounded by desert, it is built on trade and ingenuity, but also plagued by crime, inequality, and desert bandits (such as the Out Ring).

Sailzane Desert ‚Äì A massive salt desert known as "the white sea." Its pale sands conceal underground salts, and while lacking in hostile wildlife, it remains one of the most inhospitable regions of the world.

Kef ‚Äì Harsh barren deserts with little to no life aside from hardy Talyxian plants like the Mozuuk. The word ‚ÄúKef‚Äù translates to ‚Äúnothing‚Äù or ‚Äúblind alley,‚Äù reflecting the void-like quality of these lands.

Climate and Environment

Tal is a world of extremes: arid deserts, salt flats, barren rock, and strange alien forests. The Talyxian biome forests, especially in the north, are among the most dangerous ecosystems, filled with carnivorous flora, strange aquatic life, and bizarre living landscapes. Water is precious, with much of it trapped in unsafe swamps or lakes within Talyxian regions.

Inhabitants
Eltus Races

Sergals ‚Äì Native to Shigu, the most widespread race, varying from savage northerners to civilized southerners. Their culture ranges from tribal to militaristic, with strong historical ties to Rain‚Äôs Shigu Empire.

Agudners ‚Äì Resembling sturdy, bovine-like humanoids. They are technologically skilled and socially inclined toward craftsmanship, trade, and building.

Nevreans ‚Äì A birdlike race, famed for their elegance, intelligence, and artistry. They are physically dimorphic, with males slender and ornamental, and females strong and predatory.

Talyxians

Alien beings native to Tal, often insectoid, fungal, or plant-like in form. They are vastly diverse and biologically alien to the Eltus races. Many Talyxians warp their surroundings, creating strange biomes that make Tal hazardous.

Civilization and Technology

Tal‚Äôs technology generally resembles early 20th century Earth, with cars, ranged firearms, and rudimentary computers. However, technological levels vary greatly across regions:

Gold Ring resembles Earth‚Äôs Showa-era Japan in aesthetics, blending traditional living with modest industrialization.

Rural and frontier areas retain more primitive, survivalist traditions, often depending on barter and hand-crafted tools.

Talyxian technologies, alien in origin, exist in rare pockets but remain poorly understood or dangerous to Eltus peoples.

Culture and Society

Trade and Roads ‚Äì Regions like Reono are defined by commerce, with the great road to Gold Ring serving as a cultural lifeline.

Isolationist Regions ‚Äì Nevrea remains almost exclusively Nevrean, shunning integration with other peoples.

Conflict and Banditry ‚Äì Harsh environments give rise to raiders, most infamously the Out Ring, a bandit group of outcast Nevreans.

Religion and Spirituality ‚Äì Shigu‚Äôs ancient traditions emphasize reverence for the land, but under General Rain, these were twisted into militaristic zeal.

History

Pre-War Tal ‚Äì Eltus races lived in scattered regions, maintaining traditional lifestyles and often at odds with the encroaching Talyxian biomes.

The Shigu Empire (Year 40) ‚Äì General Rain unified the northern Sergals, creating a fearsome military state that waged campaigns across Tal. This era defined much of Tal‚Äôs cultural memory and reshaped its political boundaries.

Modern Tal ‚Äì Gold Ring stands as the cultural and economic heart of the world, while outlying regions remain steeped in older traditions or isolated survivalism.

2.name: Shigu
2.content:
Shigu is the vast northern region of Planet Tal, encompassing some of its harshest environments: the Astna plains, the Tatla desert, and Thekan. It is recognized as the birthplace of the Sergal race, and historically the seat of the infamous Shigu Empire under General Rain, which reshaped the entire planet‚Äôs history.

Geography

Astna Plains ‚Äì Open grasslands and steppe-like regions that were home to nomadic tribes of Northern Sergals.

Tatla Desert ‚Äì Harsh, arid terrain where survival is difficult; it acted as both a natural barrier and a resource-scarce homeland for many clans.

Thekan ‚Äì Rocky and rugged highlands, historically considered sacred ground by native Sergals.

The land is characterized by extremes: bitter winters, arid deserts, and scarce fertile zones. These conditions produced hardy peoples and deeply traditional societies.

Climate and Environment

Shigu‚Äôs northern latitude and varied terrain create sharp environmental divides:

Winters are brutal and long, with deep snow in plains and mountain passes.

Summers in the desert zones are scorching, leaving little water or vegetation.

Resources are scarce, forcing Shigu‚Äôs inhabitants into either nomadic lifestyles or militaristic expansions to acquire what they lack.

Inhabitants

Northern Sergals ‚Äì The indigenous population of Shigu. They lived in tribal societies for most of pre-war history, guided by tradition and reverence for their land. Their culture emphasized survival, strength, and spiritual connection to nature.

Eltus Minorities ‚Äì Small populations of Agudners and Nevreans existed on the fringes but were rare in these lands, often absorbed or enslaved during the Shigu Empire‚Äôs rise.

Culture and Society

Pre-Empire Traditions ‚Äì Tribal customs revolved around hunting, survival, and spiritual rites. Leaders were often chosen by merit or ritual standing rather than hereditary succession.

Spiritual Beliefs ‚Äì Before Rain‚Äôs rise, many Sergals of Shigu revered the natural cycles of their environment, honoring both life and death as necessary struggles.

Warrior Ethos ‚Äì Due to scarce resources and harsh climates, martial skill and cooperation were central to Shigu‚Äôs identity long before its unification.

The Shigu Empire

The most defining period in Shigu‚Äôs history came in Year 40, with the rise of General Rain, the great warlord and unifier of the Northern Sergals.

Unification ‚Äì Rain consolidated scattered Sergal tribes into one empire, harnessing their warrior traditions into a single military machine.

Expansionism ‚Äì The Empire launched campaigns across Tal, devastating rival regions and altering the balance of power.

Cultural Impact ‚Äì Traditional Shigu beliefs were repurposed into militaristic dogma, with Rain treated as both supreme commander and semi-divine figure.

Infamy ‚Äì While Rain‚Äôs empire forged unity, it also brought widespread death and fear, marking Shigu with a legacy of conquest and brutality.

Post-Empire Era

After Rain‚Äôs imprisonment and the collapse of centralized rule, Shigu fractured:

Many clans reverted to their old tribal systems, though heavily scarred by the war.

The memory of the Shigu Empire remains a source of both pride and trauma: pride in their strength, trauma from their association with Rain‚Äôs atrocities.

Neighboring regions often view Shigu with suspicion, associating it with savagery, war, and instability.

Themes of Shigu

Birthplace of Sergals ‚Äì The cultural and biological origin of the species.

Survival Against the Land ‚Äì Harsh conditions shaped a fierce and pragmatic people.

Glory and Infamy ‚Äì The Shigu Empire left an indelible mark on all of Tal, making Shigu synonymous with war and conquest.

Tradition vs. Transformation ‚Äì Old tribal customs clashed with Rain‚Äôs militaristic order, leaving a lasting cultural fracture.

3.name: Astna Plains
3.content:
üîπ Overview

The Astna Plains are an extensive expanse of northern Talyxian Biomes, stretching across much of the northern regions of Tal. Unlike forested areas like Zyngoe, Astna is primarily composed of open plains, wastelands, and scattered patches of forest, making it a comparatively exposed and wild environment.

This region is known as a sparsely settled frontier, with only occasional villages or outposts along rivers or salt lake edges.

Astna forms part of the homeland of the Northern Sergals, contributing to their cultural and spiritual identity.

üîπ Geography and Environment

Terrain:

Vast, open plains with rolling hills, seasonal streams, and sparse Talyxian forest clusters.

Certain areas contain salt flats or semi-arid wastelands, particularly near smaller, ephemeral lakes.

Climate:

Humid in Talyxian Biome clusters but drier across open plains.

Temperatures fluctuate moderately, with fewer extremes than southern deserts, making the plains a viable environment for exploration and limited settlement.

üîπ Flora and Fauna

Talyxian Biomes:

Predominantly red- and gray-group Talyxian organisms inhabit scattered forest patches and wetlands.

Open plains host smaller, mobile Talyxian creatures, often moving in herds or packs.

Wildlife Dynamics:

Predatory Talyxians occasionally roam across the plains, requiring vigilance for travelers and small settlements.

Many sessile ‚Äúplant-like‚Äù organisms are harvested for food, materials, or ritual purposes.

Resource Use:

Salt from seasonal flats and nearby lakes is used to protect settlements and process Talyxian materials.

Harmless creatures and plants are traded or utilized locally.

üîπ Human Interaction

Settlements:

Limited to small, semi-permanent villages along rivers or lake edges.

Northern Sergals maintain traditional lifestyles, with some Eastern Reono interaction in trade or exploration.

Exploration:

Scouts, hunters, and shamans frequently traverse the plains, observing Talyxian behavior or gathering resources.

Open terrain makes long-distance travel feasible, but exposure to Talyxian predators remains a risk.

üîπ Cultural Significance

Astna Plains are considered a spiritual heartland for Northern Sergals, associated with shamans, legends, and ancestral rites.

The plains‚Äô open vistas symbolize freedom, survival, and coexistence with Tal‚Äôs alien ecosystems.

Local folklore frequently references nomadic herds, mysterious creatures, and natural phenomena, contributing to Astna‚Äôs mythical character.

The Astna Plains are a key northern region, blending exposed plains, minor forested areas, and alien biomes into a complex ecosystem where Talyxian life and Northern Sergal culture coexist in delicate balance.

4.name: Tatla Desert
4.content:
The Tatla Desert is a massive, arid expanse within the Shigu region of northern Tal. Known for its brutal climate and desolate landscape, the desert has long been both a barrier and a crucible for the Northern Sergals who dwell there. Despite its barren nature, it played a pivotal role in shaping Shigu‚Äôs warrior culture and in the rise of the Shigu Empire under General Rain.

Geography

The desert spans a wide area of Shigu, bordering the Astna Plains to the south and the Thekan Highlands to the east.

The land consists mostly of dry sand, cracked earth, and wind-carved stone ridges.

There are few landmarks, though scattered rocky outcrops and shallow basins provide rare shelter.

Climate and Environment

Daytime Heat ‚Äì Temperatures soar under a relentless sun, making water and shade precious commodities.

Nighttime Cold ‚Äì After sundown, temperatures plummet, often dropping below freezing.

Rainfall ‚Äì Extremely scarce; most precipitation evaporates before reaching the ground.

Flora and Fauna ‚Äì Life is sparse but hardy. Small Talyxian plants like thorny cacti and deep-rooted shrubs survive, while some insectoid and reptilian Talyxians have adapted to the extreme conditions. Large predators are rare, but nomads must remain vigilant for ambushes.

Inhabitants

Northern Sergal Tribes ‚Äì Some clans adapted to desert life, moving seasonally between scarce water sources. These tribes are renowned for their endurance and ability to live with minimal resources.

Nomadic Outcasts ‚Äì The Tatla Desert has historically served as a refuge for outcasts and defeated clans, forcing them to eke out survival in the harshest conditions.

Culture and Society

Life in the Tatla Desert produced Sergals of formidable resilience:

Water as Wealth ‚Äì Ownership of wells or oases defined power, with entire clans rising and falling over these lifelines.

Raid and Trade ‚Äì Desert tribes frequently raided travelers, or traded water and desert-crafted goods for food and tools from the Astna Plains.

Spirituality of Scarcity ‚Äì Some tribes believed the desert itself was a living trial, a spiritual test that burned away weakness and left only the strong and pure.

Historical Role

Pre-Empire ‚Äì Desert clans were small and fiercely independent, relying on mobility and raiding to survive. They were often feared by plains-dwelling Sergals for their toughness and cunning.

Rise of Rain ‚Äì General Rain famously used the Tatla Desert as a proving ground, testing the loyalty and endurance of her followers. Survival in Tatla became a badge of honor for warriors, and control over its few resources was crucial for her campaigns.

Shigu Empire ‚Äì Under Rain, Tatla was transformed into both a training ground and a symbolic heart of conquest. Armies marched through its harsh expanse to prove their discipline, and its unforgiving nature became an allegory for the Empire‚Äôs strength.

Post-Empire ‚Äì With Rain‚Äôs downfall, the desert returned to its fragmented tribal roots. However, many clans still tell stories of the great marches and battles that once scarred the sands.

Themes of the Tatla Desert

Harsh Teacher ‚Äì The land itself acts as a trial, weeding out the weak and forging survivors.

Isolation and Resilience ‚Äì The desert breeds independent, stubborn clans who prize endurance.

Legacy of Rain ‚Äì Once a feared wasteland, it became an icon of Shigu‚Äôs warlike unity under the Empire.

Cycle of Struggle ‚Äì Even after the Empire‚Äôs fall, the Tatla Desert remains a place where life is measured by the ability to withstand hardship.

5.name: Thekan
5.content:
Thekan is a rugged highland and mountainous zone within Shigu, forming one of the defining regions of northern Tal alongside the Astna Plains and the Tatla Desert. Known for its harsh cliffs, rocky valleys, and sacred sites, Thekan has long been a place of spiritual importance to Northern Sergals, even before the rise of the Shigu Empire.

Geography

Landscape ‚Äì Jagged mountains, steep ridges, and wide rocky plateaus dominate Thekan. Its terrain is far less forgiving than the open Astna Plains or Tatla Desert, offering little flat land for settlement.

Caves and Grottos ‚Äì The cliffs are riddled with caves, many of which were historically used as shelters, sacred sites, or burial grounds.

Natural Borders ‚Äì Thekan‚Äôs rough terrain acted as a natural fortress, difficult for outsiders to invade and equally difficult for armies to march through.

Climate and Environment

Cold and Harsh ‚Äì Thekan experiences long winters, with snow often lingering well into spring.

Sparse Resources ‚Äì Vegetation is limited to hardy shrubs, mosses, and highland grasses.

Wildlife ‚Äì Mountain-dwelling Talyxian beasts adapted to steep terrain are common, ranging from goat-like grazers to predatory bird-forms. Hunting them requires skill and teamwork.

Water ‚Äì Snowmelt provides seasonal streams, but year-round fresh water sources are rare.

Inhabitants

Highland Sergals ‚Äì Smaller populations of Northern Sergals lived here in comparison to the plains. Highland clans valued seclusion, resilience, and spiritual closeness to the land.

Hermits and Shamans ‚Äì Before Rain, Thekan was renowned as a place where mystics and shamans retreated for visions and rituals, seeking communion with Tal‚Äôs natural and spiritual forces.

Culture and Society

Sacred Ground ‚Äì Thekan was often viewed as the ‚Äúspiritual heart‚Äù of Shigu, with rituals and gatherings held in its caves and mountain passes.

Burial Rites ‚Äì Many clans interred their dead in Thekan‚Äôs caverns, believing the mountains to be eternal guardians of their ancestors.

Trial by Exile ‚Äì Some tribes sent individuals into Thekan as a form of spiritual trial or punishment. Survival in the highlands was seen as proof of worthiness or divine favor.

Warrior‚Äôs Path ‚Äì Young warriors sometimes underwent rites of passage in Thekan, hunting dangerous beasts in the cliffs to earn honor.

Historical Role

Pre-Empire ‚Äì Thekan was primarily a place of pilgrimage, ritual, and small isolated settlements. It contributed little to warfare but a great deal to the spiritual identity of Shigu.

Rise of Rain ‚Äì General Rain co-opted Thekan‚Äôs spiritual importance, using it to legitimize her authority. She was said to have undertaken rituals in its sacred caves, presenting herself as chosen by destiny. This transformed Thekan from a holy land into a political tool.

Shigu Empire ‚Äì Thekan‚Äôs caves and mountains became fortresses, supply caches, and places of military training. The sacred and the martial were fused, with Rain demanding both faith and obedience.

Post-Empire ‚Äì After Rain‚Äôs fall, Thekan partially returned to its traditional role as a sacred land. However, its spiritual legacy remains stained by its use as propaganda and stronghold during the Shigu Empire.

Themes of Thekan

Sanctuary and Trial ‚Äì A place where life is harsh, but where spiritual purity and endurance are tested.

Sacred Authority ‚Äì Thekan‚Äôs holiness was both a source of inspiration and a tool for political control under Rain.

Isolation and Resilience ‚Äì Those who lived here embodied the toughest, most ascetic aspects of Sergal life.

Legacy of Faith and War ‚Äì Its caves still echo with both prayers and the memory of imperial mustering grounds.

6.name: Nevrea
6.content:
Nevrea is the ancestral homeland of the Nevrean race, located in the western lands of Planet Tal. It is a region defined by the towering Nev Mountains, overlapping forests, and a culture of isolation and self-sufficiency. Unlike other regions of Tal, Nevrea is inhabited exclusively by Nevreans, who maintain a fiercely distinct identity apart from Sergals and Agudners.

Geography

Nev Mountains ‚Äì A vast mountain range dominates the region, with steep cliffs, alpine valleys, and snowy peaks.

Vetla Forest ‚Äì Dense forests cover the northern flanks of the Nev Mountains, rich in alien flora from the encroaching Talyxian biomes.

Borderlands ‚Äì Harsh foothills and forest edges form natural barriers separating Nevrea from neighboring regions like Reono.

The terrain is challenging, with limited farmland, narrow valleys, and difficult passes that discourage large-scale settlements by outsiders.

Climate and Environment

Cold and Variable ‚Äì Mountain weather shifts quickly, with cold winters and short, cool summers.

Forested Zones ‚Äì The Vetla forest is thick and often dangerous, with Talyxian lifeforms inhabiting its deeper reaches.

Resources ‚Äì Wildlife, mountain herbs, and forest products sustain the Nevreans. Large-scale agriculture is rare due to terrain, though terraced farming exists in some valleys.

Inhabitants

Nevreans ‚Äì The sole native inhabitants. The region is considered their birthplace and cultural heart.

Other Eltus Races ‚Äì None. Nevrea is one of the few regions of Tal without Sergals or Agudners. Outsiders are not welcome and rarely tolerated.

Culture and Society

Nevrea‚Äôs society reflects the Nevreans‚Äô unique biology and worldview:

Gender Dimorphism ‚Äì Female Nevreans are stronger, predatory, and more physically dominant, while males are slender, ornamental, and socially prized for beauty, intelligence, and artistry. This dimorphism heavily shapes Nevrea‚Äôs traditions and gender roles.

Isolationism ‚Äì Nevreans avoid mixing with other Eltus races, maintaining cultural purity and self-sufficiency.

Art and Aesthetics ‚Äì Nevreans are renowned for their elegance, ornamentation, and cultural refinement, with music, crafts, and fashion highly developed.

Predatory Hierarchy ‚Äì While more ‚Äúcivilized‚Äù than Shigu tribes, Nevrean society still holds an undertone of predatory dominance, especially from females.

Territorial Pride ‚Äì Nevrea is considered sacred and inviolable; outsiders are rarely allowed to cross its borders.

Historical Role

Pre-War Era ‚Äì Nevrea remained insular, avoiding the conflicts of neighboring regions. While Sergals fought tribal wars or later built empires, Nevreans kept to their mountains.

The Shigu Empire ‚Äì Rain‚Äôs armies had little impact on Nevrea due to its natural defenses and the Nevreans‚Äô resistance to foreign presence. Unlike Reono and Gold Ring, Nevrea was never truly conquered.

Modern Era ‚Äì Nevrea continues to stand apart. While Gold Ring has grown into a cosmopolitan center and Reono thrives on trade, Nevrea remains uniquely Nevrean, aloof from broader Tal society.

Themes of Nevrea

Isolation and Purity ‚Äì A land closed to outsiders, maintaining cultural and racial exclusivity.

Elegance and Predation ‚Äì A society balancing beauty, refinement, and the raw predatory instincts of its people.

Strong Female Dominance ‚Äì Social structures reflect the biological reality of female strength and male delicacy.

Cultural Pride ‚Äì Nevreans see themselves as distinct from, and often superior to, the other Eltus races.

7.name: Nev Mountains
7.content:
The Nev Mountains form the dominant natural feature of Nevrea, rising like a vast barrier along the western lands of Planet Tal. Rugged, snow-capped, and densely forested at their bases, the Nev Mountains are both a protective wall and the cradle of the Nevrean race. They define Nevrea‚Äôs culture, isolation, and survival, acting as both sanctuary and stronghold.

Geography

Range ‚Äì The Nev Mountains extend across most of Nevrea, forming a near-impassable natural boundary against the outside world.

Peaks and Passes ‚Äì High peaks are snow-covered year-round, while narrow passes act as the only viable routes into Nevrea. These routes are treacherous and often deliberately hidden or guarded by locals.

Valleys ‚Äì Deep valleys nestled between ridges house Nevrean settlements, sheltered from harsh winds but still isolated.

Vetla Forest ‚Äì Along the northern flanks of the Nev Mountains, this dense woodland overlaps the range, mixing alpine and alien Talyxian ecology.

Climate and Environment

Cold Alpine Climate ‚Äì Long, snowy winters dominate, with short but fertile summers that sustain localized farming.

Unpredictable Weather ‚Äì Sudden storms, avalanches, and freezing winds make the mountains difficult for outsiders to traverse.

Resources ‚Äì

Game animals provide meat, hides, and bone tools.

Herbal and medicinal plants grow in sheltered valleys.

Minerals and stone are plentiful, giving rise to skilled Nevrean craftsmanship.

Inhabitants

Nevreans ‚Äì The Nev Mountains are their birthplace and homeland, with all Nevrean cultural identity tied to the mountains. Settlements are built in valleys or along ridges, often blending with the landscape for concealment.

Other Races ‚Äì Virtually absent. The Nev Mountains serve as a natural exclusion zone against Sergals and Agudners, who rarely venture here and are unwelcome.

Culture and Society

Life in the Nev Mountains shaped Nevrean society in distinctive ways:

Isolation and Defense ‚Äì The mountains protect Nevrea from invasion, enabling the Nevreans‚Äô cultural insularity. Their passes are natural chokepoints that make conquest nearly impossible.

Gender Dynamics ‚Äì Female Nevreans dominate physical labor, hunting, and defense, while males focus on artistry, scholarship, and aesthetics. This split is deeply reinforced by mountain life, where both roles are necessary for survival.

Settlements ‚Äì Small, self-sufficient communities are nestled in valleys or cliffside terraces. Each is largely independent but shares cultural ties with the greater whole of Nevrea.

Spiritual Connection ‚Äì The mountains are seen as sacred, eternal guardians of Nevrean heritage. Myths often describe the first Nevreans as ‚Äúhatched from the Nev peaks.‚Äù

Historical Role

Pre-War Era ‚Äì The Nev Mountains provided security, keeping Nevreans insulated from the chaos of Shigu‚Äôs tribal wars. While Sergals and Agudners clashed elsewhere, Nevrea‚Äôs mountain passes discouraged invasion.

Shigu Empire ‚Äì Even at its height, Rain‚Äôs Empire struggled to penetrate the Nev Mountains. Harsh geography and staunch Nevrean resistance prevented full conquest. Nevrea remained one of the few regions of Tal to preserve autonomy.

Modern Era ‚Äì The Nev Mountains still shield Nevrea from outside influence. While Gold Ring and Reono embrace trade and multicultural exchange, Nevrea remains a closed, mountain-locked society.

Themes of the Nev Mountains

Barrier and Sanctuary ‚Äì Impassable walls that keep Nevrea safe but also isolated.

Cultural Cradle ‚Äì The birthplace of Nevreans, inseparable from their identity and traditions.

Strength through Separation ‚Äì The mountains enforce Nevrea‚Äôs exclusivity, ensuring it remains uniquely Nevrean.

Sacred Permanence ‚Äì Symbol of stability and endurance in contrast to the shifting politics of Tal‚Äôs other regions.

8.name: Vetla Forest
8.content:
The Vetla Forest is a dense, shadowed woodland that stretches along the northern slopes of the Nev Mountains in Nevrea. It represents one of the border zones where traditional Eltus environments meet the alien Talyxian biome, creating a mysterious and dangerous ecosystem. For the Nevreans, the Vetla Forest is both a resource and a peril ‚Äî a place of hunting, gathering, and myth, but also of lurking threats.

Geography

Location ‚Äì The forest spreads across the northern flanks of the Nev Mountains, spilling into the foothills and bordering the greater western wildlands.

Terrain ‚Äì Thick canopies block sunlight, leaving the forest floor dim and damp. The ground is uneven with root tangles, ravines, and moss-choked boulders.

Overlap Zone ‚Äì Parts of the Vetla Forest show traits of Talyxian biome encroachment, where alien growths, fungi, and hybrid plant-life intermingle with traditional woodland.

Climate and Environment

Climate ‚Äì Cool and damp, with mist common at dawn and dusk. Snow dusts the forest in winter, but much of it melts quickly under the canopy.

Flora ‚Äì Towering conifers and twisted hardwoods dominate, often covered with moss and lichen. In areas of Talyxian intrusion, bizarre fungi, bioluminescent plants, and thorny alien vines spread unnaturally.

Fauna ‚Äì

Traditional Wildlife: Mountain deer, small mammals, and birds form the prey base.

Talyxian Intrusions: Insectoid predators, strange carnivorous plants, and parasitic spores lurk in deeper or corrupted areas.

Inhabitants

Nevreans ‚Äì The Vetla Forest is an important resource zone for Nevrea, though not a primary site of habitation. Nevreans hunt its wildlife, gather herbs, and use its timber, but always with caution.

Other Eltus Races ‚Äì Absent, as Nevrea itself is closed to outsiders.

Talyxian Creatures ‚Äì Highly variable and often dangerous. The forest‚Äôs reputation stems largely from their unpredictable presence.

Culture and Society

For Nevreans, the Vetla Forest has a complex role in their traditions:

Resource Gathering ‚Äì Herbs, rare fungi, and medicinal plants are prized harvests from Vetla.

Hunting Ground ‚Äì Female Nevreans often prove their strength by hunting within Vetla, especially in its darker, Talyxian-touched zones.

Myth and Superstition ‚Äì The forest is wrapped in folklore. Tales speak of hunters swallowed whole by living trees, or spirits that whisper through the mists.

Ritual Space ‚Äì Some Nevrean rites of passage involve surviving or completing a task within the forest.

Historical Role

Pre-War Nevrea ‚Äì The forest served as a natural boundary and cultural anchor. While Nevreans controlled its edges, they never fully subdued the deeper Talyxian pockets.

Shigu Empire Era ‚Äì Rain‚Äôs expansion largely ignored Nevrea, and thus Vetla remained untouched by large-scale war. However, stories circulated of Shigu scouts who tried to cross the forest, only to vanish in its alien depths.

Modern Nevrea ‚Äì The Vetla Forest continues to be used cautiously. Its alien edges remain mysterious, with parts still unexplored even by the Nevreans themselves.

Themes of the Vetla Forest

Border of the Known and Unknown ‚Äì A threshold between the safe Nev Mountains and the alien Talyxian wilderness.

Resource and Danger ‚Äì Life-giving herbs and food exist alongside deadly predators and corruption.

Mystery and Myth ‚Äì A land of half-remembered legends, feared spirits, and dangerous hunts.

Cultural Trial ‚Äì For Nevreans, the Vetla Forest is both a proving ground and a reminder of their vulnerability.

9.name: Borderlands
9.content:
The Borderlands refer to the transitional regions of Planet Tal where the stable, life-supporting Eltus environments meet and blend into the unstable, alien Talyxian biome. Unlike clear territorial divisions, the Borderlands are shifting and overlapping ecological frontiers, constantly reshaped by natural growth, climate, and the unpredictable expansion of Talyxian organisms.

They are some of the most mysterious and dangerous zones on Tal, feared as much as they are respected. For all Eltus races, the Borderlands symbolize the thin line between civilization and alien wilderness.

Geography and Distribution

Location ‚Äì Borderlands exist all across Tal, wherever Eltus regions press against Talyxian biomes. Examples include:

The northern reaches of Nevrea, where the Vetla Forest blends into alien growth.

Edges of the Astna Plains and Tatla Desert, where shifting sands and strange lifeforms meet.

Zones around the great Talyxian Swamps in the north.

Terrain ‚Äì Often irregular and unstable: twisted forests, corrupted wetlands, and rocky barrens where alien flora roots in Eltus soil.

Climate and Environment

Weather ‚Äì Highly unpredictable, often shifting between familiar seasonal patterns and strange alien phenomena.

Flora ‚Äì

Eltus Plants: Normal trees, grasses, and herbs exist but often warped or overgrown.

Talyxian Growths: Giant fungi, spore-producing stalks, and luminous or crystalline plants that defy natural cycles.

Fauna ‚Äì

Hybrid Zones: Eltus wildlife may coexist with alien predators, often hunted or outcompeted.

Talyxian Creatures: Many are aggressive, parasitic, or highly territorial, making Borderlands travel perilous.

Inhabitants and Culture

Eltus Races ‚Äì Permanent habitation is rare, but some groups live on the edge of Borderlands, exploiting their resources.

Nevreans venture into forest-border zones for hunting and herbs.

Eastern Sergals and Agudners in Reono sometimes graze animals near safer borders.

Talyxians ‚Äì The deeper Borderlands are dominated by alien life that can never be tamed or fully understood.

Cultural Role ‚Äì

A place of myths and taboos, often described as ‚Äúhaunted‚Äù or cursed.

Used for rites of passage: warriors, hunters, or shamans proving themselves by surviving or retrieving something from the Borderlands.

Feared as gateways to being ‚Äúlost to the alien,‚Äù a phrase meaning assimilation, corruption, or death.

Historical Significance

Pre-War Eras ‚Äì Borderlands always served as natural boundaries between settled civilizations and the alien unknown.

Shigu Empire Era ‚Äì Many of Shigu‚Äôs northern campaigns were halted or diverted by Talyxian Borderlands, as armies could not sustain themselves in alien regions.

Modern Times ‚Äì With trade routes and settlements expanding, Borderlands remain dangerous barriers. Expeditions often vanish, reinforcing their mythic danger.

Themes of the Borderlands

Threshold of Survival ‚Äì Civilization ends where the Borderlands begin.

Constant Encroachment ‚Äì The alien world is always pressing in on Eltus lands, reminding races of their fragility.

Mystery and Horror ‚Äì Strange sounds, lights, and creatures make the Borderlands a place of awe and fear.

Cultural Crucible ‚Äì A place where bravery, recklessness, or desperation is tested.

10.name: Reono
10.content:
Reono is a major cultural and geographical region located across the Eastern to Middle Eltus lands of Planet Tal. It is the homeland of the Eastern Sergals and Eastern Agudners, two races that share a long history of cooperation and cultural interweaving. Reono acts as a vibrant hub of trade, tradition, and agriculture, serving as the Eastern counterbalance to the southern city of Gold Ring.

Geography

Location ‚Äì Reono stretches broadly from the middle heartlands of Tal toward the eastern territories, creating a corridor between southern Gold Ring and the more remote eastern plains.

Terrain ‚Äì

Fertile grasslands, farmlands, and valleys form the core.

Forested ridges and low hills are common along the western edge.

Some steppes and dry plains mark its easternmost boundaries.

Travel and Roads ‚Äì Reono contains the Great Eastern Road, a vital trade artery connecting Gold Ring with the Eastern territories and Middle Eltus regions.

Climate and Environment

Climate ‚Äì Mild to warm, with fertile soils supporting farming and grazing. Winters are less harsh than in the north, but occasional cold winds sweep down from the Nev Mountains.

Flora and Fauna ‚Äì

Rich agricultural crops: grains, fruits, and vegetables.

Domesticated animals like pack beasts and herd livestock, tended especially by Agudners.

Forests in the west provide lumber and hunting grounds.

Inhabitants

Eastern Sergals ‚Äì

Characterized by smaller, more agile builds compared to their Northern kin.

Known for adaptability, sharp social instincts, and an agricultural lifestyle blended with hunting traditions.

They are the most numerous race in Reono.

Eastern Agudners ‚Äì

Distinguished by their agricultural expertise, craft skills, and pragmatic nature.

Deeply tied to farming, animal husbandry, and trade, often serving as merchants and craftspeople.

Other Eltus Races ‚Äì Rare in Reono, though Gold Ring‚Äôs influence occasionally brings outsiders through trade.

Culture and Society

Lifestyle ‚Äì

Strong emphasis on community and cooperation. Sergals and Agudners live side by side, balancing martial instincts with practical skill.

Villages and towns often combine both races harmoniously, unlike many other regions that remain racially homogenous.

Economy ‚Äì

Farming and herding form the base of Reono‚Äôs wealth.

Trade caravans carry goods northward and southward, using the Great Eastern Road.

Known exports: grains, textiles, crafted tools, and livestock.

Cultural Exchange ‚Äì

Sergals contribute hunting traditions, music, and festivals rooted in seasonal cycles.

Agudners contribute craftwork, agriculture, and record-keeping.

Together, Reono culture is remembered as balanced and pragmatic.

History

Pre-War Era ‚Äì Reono was a flourishing agricultural and trade zone, largely shielded from the harsher northern conflicts. Its prosperity came from cooperation between Sergals and Agudners.

Shigu Empire Era ‚Äì The expansion of General Rain reached Reono during the war years. Though not the epicenter of violence like Shigu or Nevrea, Reono still suffered losses from raids, famine, and forced levies. However, its mixed population proved resilient and adapted quickly after the empire‚Äôs fall.

Modern Times ‚Äì Reono remains a strong and stable region. It has rebuilt its trade networks with Gold Ring and beyond, and its mixed cultural identity has become a defining feature.

Themes of Reono

Balance of Races ‚Äì The coexistence of Eastern Sergals and Agudners makes Reono unique among Tal‚Äôs regions.

Trade and Connection ‚Äì Its roads tie Gold Ring to the East, making it vital for economic flow.

Resilience ‚Äì Though affected by the Shigu wars, Reono endured and adapted through cooperation.

Cultural Harmony ‚Äì A region where differences are embraced, leading to strength.

1.name: Class 1-A
1.content:
Class 1-A (1Âπ¥„Å≠„ÇìA„Ç®„ÉºÁµÑ„Åê„Åø Ichi-nen ƒí-gumi?) is the homeroom class of the main protagonist Izuku Midoriya and one of the main settings of My Hero Academia.
After the Final War, the class has become second-years and Hitoshi Shinso has taken Yuga Aoyama's place after he left U.A. High School.

Eight years later, everyone in Class A became the new generation of Heroes in Japan.

Mina Ashido: Seat No. 2
